1.t: You can do many things on the internet – shop, learn, email, watch movies – but something else that people spend a lot of time with is: social media.

a: TV shows that talk about society. Like soap operas!
Places on the internet where people share content and talk about it.

1.t: Social media are places on the internet where people share content and talk about it. They include Facebook, TikTok, YouTube, Instagram, and LinkedIn. Let's take a closer look at them...
Social media are places on the internet where people share content and talk about it. They include Facebook, TikTok, YouTube, Instagram, and LinkedIn. Let's take a closer look at them...
FACEBOOK has text, messaging, pictures, and videos. People use Facebook to keep in touch with friends and family, join groups, read and share news, and talk about things they like.

i.a: The Facebook page for GBH, showing photos of the building, plus stories about PBS Newshour and Frontline

1.t: YOUTUBE focuses on longer videos. People share their thoughts, show people how to do things, share clips from TV and movies, share music they've created, and pretty much anything else you can watch.

i.a: The YouTube homepage for GBH, including thumbnails for videos about travel, writers, and musicians

1.t: YOUTUBE SHORTS, TIKTOK and INSTAGRAM REELS all show very short videos. They can be silly or serious but are usually posted to make people want to share them.

Many sites do more than one thing. YouTube also has live events, while Instagram also has lots of pictures and news. Facebook has places to buy and sell things. And they all have a lot of advertising and promotion.
LINKEDIN is the only one of these to focus on jobs and careers. Many people use LinkedIn to show their work experience, and to look for work.

i.a: The LinkedIn profile page of Jane Wilson, a senior account executive. It shows that she works in Massachusetts, has 414 connections, attended Mass University, and shows some of her previous jobs

1.t: On any of these platforms, you can CREATE content, just LOOK at what others have created, or WRITE comments.

2.t: But along with all the fun things you can do on social media, there are many things to watch out for, too.
Why are these social media services mostly free?
a: They're not free. You "pay" with your private information and by seeing ads.
They're free because the government pays for them.

2.t: Although you don't have to pay to use them, these services collect all the information you post, and may sell it to other companies so they can target you with specific ads.
Although you don't have to pay to use them, these services collect all the information you post, and may sell it to other companies so they can target you with specific ads.

3.t: If you post something to social media, but then want to delete it, how easy is that to do?

It's very hard to remove content – or even just a comment – from social media. And even if you do delete it, people may have already seen it or even made a copy of it. So remember: always think before posting content or comments.

4.t: How much information in social media is fact-checked?
Very little information in social media is fact-checked. Many images you see online are totally false, like this flat Earth image. Even things that look real may not be true.

i.a: A picture showing the Earth and the Moon as if they were flat

5.t: Another thing to watch out for are fake social accounts set up by scammers – who then contact you in hopes that you will "friend" them or "follow" them. Once that happens, they may try to get personal information from you, or trick you into giving them money.
What clues do you see that this might not be a real account?

i.a: A Facebook profile page for Jane Doe. Information on the page show that she joined Facebook three days ago, has two friends, and has no posts

5.t: First, look for the date the account was created. If it's brand new, that's a clue it may be a scammer trying to trick you.

i.a: The Facebook profile page, with highlighted information that Jane joined three days ago

5.t: Accounts that have very few followers are suspicious. If you don't know who they are, you should probably ignore this request.

i.a: The Facebook profile page, with highlighted information that Jane has two friends

5.t: A final danger sign: people on Facebook and other social media sites usually post a lot about their friends, their family, and what interests them. If the account doesn't have many posts, that could be another sign this is fake.

i.a: The Facebook profile page, with highlighted information that Jane has no posts available
